content.content: Cabot Renewable Energy Key Terms, Structured Transaction Review, and Risk Assessment Introduction Cabot Renewable Energy Crypto Mining LLC (“Cabot”) is wholly owned by Exos Capital LLC (“Exos Capital”). Exos Capital is an affiliate of Exos TFP Holdings LLC (including its affiliates, “Exos”). Exos was founded in 2017, and detailed information about Exos is available below and at https://www.exosfinancial.com/. Cabot will acquire and control approximately 3,000 Bitcoin mining machines to be co-located with other Exos crypto miners in Paraguay. Exos’s purpose-built facility in Paraguay has direct access to renewable hydroelectric power making the facility both carbon neutral and highly cost-effective. Exos has been relocating existing miners from North America to Paraguay, and the Cabot proposal is an expansion of the mining capacity at this facility. Exos seeks to work with MakerDAO to expand and further decentralize cryptocurrency mining activities in a manner which is both cost-effective and environmentally sustainable. As detailed below, Exos seeks to narrow and prewire most aspects of the transaction to reduce MakerDAO’s operational, monitoring, and build-out requirements. In particular, (x) Cabot will be organized as a limited purpose LLC domiciled in the U.S., (y) Exos Capital will pledge its interest in Cabot to MakerDAO (or its designee), and (z) mining machine valuations will be preset based on a 5-year final life. The following content is intended to supplement and clarify the “MIP6: Cabot Renewable Energy Crypto Mining” collateral onboarding submission of June 2, 2022 on the MakerDAO Forum, consistent with MakerDAO’s MIP67 and related guidance. Definitions and terms should be assumed to be consistent unless otherwise indicated. Transaction Overview An equivalent dollar value of $15 million of Cabot-owned machines will serve as the collateral for the proposed DAI amount of $12 million (i.e., an initial 80% collateral value). Collateral will be returned in equal installments over four years (the “Project Term”). For the purposes of the project, Cabot assumes that the collateral value of the machines will decline linearly by $3 million per year (20% of the original valuation) over each year of the Project Term, and Exos Capital’s $3 million contribution will remain subordinated to MakerDAO’s interest throughout the Project Term. Loan-to-values (“LTVs”) based on straight-line re-valuation of the collateral are projected as 75%, 66%, 50%, and 0% for MakerDAO on each anniversary of commencement of the Project as collateral is returned. For the purposes of collateral return and collateral valuations, the Project Term has a half-life of two-years, and the machines are assumed to have a half-life of 2 ½ years. The Cabot machines will be part of Exos’s larger hydro-powered operation in Paraguay. Cabot will be organized as a limited purpose LLC organized in Delaware, and Cabot will maintain independent partners with services available in both the U.S. and Paraguay to assist with operational and logistical support. As detailed below, Cabot will fund a wallet for the purpose of covering the operational set-up, shipping, transfer, or liquidation of Cabot’s miners in the remote event that MakerDAO acquires control of Cabot and its assets as a result of a collateral recovery or liquidation event. Cabot will be formed and organized prior to a final approval of the proposal. As discussed above, Cabot will operate as a limited purpose entity, organized solely for the purposes of collateral isolation and management. For the avoidance of doubt, Cabot will be restricted from activities not related to acquiring the miners, operating and maintaining its miners, and causing the payment of yield and return of collateral to MakerDAO (“Limited Activities”). Cabot’s is restricted from borrowings or other indebtedness not in direct support of the Limited Activities. The credit support for the transaction will be a pledge of Exos’ equity interests in Cabot, as described in [Q36] of Cabot’s MIP6 proposal: “To ensure that MakerDAO has access to the collateral, Exos Capital will pledge its equity interests in Cabot to MakerDAO, which, at the direction of MakerDAO, may necessitate the filing of a financing statement under the Uniform Commercial Code naming MakerDAO or its designee as “secured party”. Exos will serve as the “Operator” of Cabot’s Bitcoin mining assets. Exos anticipates performing the operational, settlement and day-to-day work with its in-house staff, drawing from its trading, operations, accounting/reporting, legal, and compliance personnel. As of June 30, 2022, Exos and its affiliates have more than 80 professionals worldwide. Key Transaction Terms  image1127×1281 92 KB   Subject to market conditions, Exos can assist MakerDAO-MIP6 in identifying similar collateralization arrangements with other parties in other mining locations  Scheduled Valuations, Exchanges, and Cash Flows The table provided below illustrates the preset collateral valuations, returns of collateral, yield on outstanding collateral amounts, and MakerDAO credit support. As depicted in column “Miner Machine PreSet Val. Schedule”, for the purposes of both return of collateral and collateral support, machines will be valued with a 2.5yr half-life with straight-line preset value depreciation over 5 years; 5 years is consistent with industry consensus. Because the project term is 4 years, the original subordinated amount is retained throughout the life of the Project Term. Column “DAI Collateral Return” indicates the scheduled return of collateral. Annually, Cabot is obligated to cause Exos Cap to return the full amount of the preset collateral decline per year ($3m Dai) in addition to the interest payments illustrated in column “6.00% Interest Payments”. In addition to the transaction being de-risked through both preset collateral valuations and annual returns of collateral, the credit support to MakerDAO increases over the Project Term as measured with reference to both the original investment amount (“Invested Amt Coverage Ratio”) and the preset valuation (“Preset Decline Coverage Ratio”).  image716×143 13.5 KB  Transaction Detail Figure Time_1 Exos Capital, Cabot, and MakerDAO will execute the tri-party transaction depicted in Figure Time_1 where (1) Exos Capital contributes $3 million to Cabot, and (2) MakerDAO delivers 12 million Dai to Cabot in exchange for a contractual pledge over Cabot from Exos Capital (or at MakerDAO’s election, a designee to take delivery of the equity pledge).  Figure Time_2 Following Figure Time_1, Cabot will acquire miners for cash, and miner acquisitions will be recorded on-chain with identifying collateral detail and the related return-of-collateral schedules. Beginning at (Figure Time_2) Step 1, Cabot will exchange Dai amounts for US dollars, in stages, in an aggregate amount of Dai 12 million. US dollar proceeds will be used to purchase mining machines. Moving to (Figure Time_2) Step 2, Cabot will purchase machines from vendors in one or more individual orders and transactions; mining machine orders will be grouped, staged and staggered based on market conditions and availability.  The composition of the mining machines will be subject to market conditions and will be approximately 3,000 Micro BT M30S+ machines (~95 Ths, 3,327W), or equivalent, with an acquisition value of at least $15 million U.S. dollars. Cabot assets will be comprised of: (a) a wallet for Dai (for both initial Dai and Dai repayments), (b) the mining machines, (c) NFTs which will serve solely as on-chain recording of each DAI-for-machine deployment and each DAI collateral return, and (d) the Unwind Expenses Wallet – see Figure Time_3 below. Cabot will record the deployment of DAI-for-miners on-chain through the minting of NFTs (Figure Time_2, Step 4). For simplicity, we have indicated that the NFTs are held by Cabot, but they could also be held by MakerDAO or a designee if MakerDAO prefers that arrangement. While the NFTs are not critical to success of the project or the return of collateral, the NFTs minted and burned to track to DAI deployments and DAI returns will conform with the ERC-721 standard and will be used solely for the purpose of on-chain recording. Moving to (Figure Time_2) Step 3, Exos’s capital is in the form of U.S. dollars or mining machines pending delivery. For the avoidance of doubt, all US $15 million in machines will be recorded on-chain, but the subordinated amount ($3 million of the $15 million mining machines) representing Exos’ equity in the project will be recorded on-chain without return of collateral details; this $3 million amount serves as “failure-to-return-collateral” credit enhancement, but is not subject to repayment under ordinary circumstances. Figure Time_2, Step 4 indicates the on-chain recording of Dai-for-machines and is detailed below in Figure Time_2’.  Figure Time_2’ Concurrent with the delivery of mining machines, Cabot will cause on-chain recording through NFTs which will contain a listing of the individual machines and the corresponding Dai repayment schedule. As indicated at (Figure Time_2’) “C”, recording will include dates, machine detail (e.g. manufacturer, serial number, make and model) and return of collateral detail. Since repayment will occur over four years, each Dai-for-miner deployment will be recorded as 4 NFTs (e.g., NFT N_1, N_2, N_3, and N_4) where “N” is the deployment identifier, and 1 through 4 indicate the annual DAI repayment obligation. Accordingly, the first deployment of Dai-for-miners is recorded as “NFT 1_1”, “NFT 1_2”, “NFT 1_3” and “NFT 1_4” and the nth deployment will be recorded as “NFT N_[1-4]”). As noted above, there are expected to be a number of deployments as the miners are expected to be purchased in a number of separate transactions. Following each annual collateral return, the corresponding NFTs will be burned (see Figure Time_2’, “B” in diagram below).  Figure Time_3 To cover expenses associated with an unexpected liquidation of Cabot and/or the mining machines, Cabot will cause Exos Capital to deposit the first $250,000 of mining revenues generated by Cabot’s miners in a wallet held at Cabot (the “Unwind Expenses Wallet” – see Figure Time_3, Step 1). Generally, mining revenue in excess of $250,000 (plus/minus true-ups) will be remitted to Exos Capital – see Figure Time_3, Step 1. The Unwind Expenses Wallet will hold approximately $250,000 in value, which may be a combination of cryptocurrency generated by the miners and stable coins including Dai. In the event that the value of the Unwind Expenses Wallet falls below $250,000, Cabot will cause Exos Capital to add additional amounts to the wallet in quarterly true-ups. Similarly, when the value of the Unwind Expenses Wallet exceeds $250,000, Cabot will cause Exos Capital to transfer the excess to Exos Capital. The Unwind Expenses Wallet will be assessed and, if needed, cured for any true-ups on a quarterly basis. The funds held in the Unwind Expenses Wallet are available to pay for the costs of liquidation of the collateral as detailed below. When Dai 12 million collateral (plus the collateral yield) has been fully returned, any claims MakerDAO may have over the equity interests of Cabot, including any claim to the miners and any amounts held at Cabot, including the Unwind Expenses Wallet, are extinguished.  Figure Time_4 The return of collateral is scheduled to occur in equal installments on each anniversary. On each of the four Project Term anniversaries, Cabot will direct Exos Capital to return 25% of the original collateral amount (Dai 3 million) plus the yield amount for the period (Figure Time_4, Step 1). Concurrently, Dai 3 million plus the yield amount will be returned to MakerDAO (Figure Time_4, Step 1’) and Cabot will cause the related NFT(s), which recorded the scheduled return of collateral, to be burned (Figure Time_4, Step 1’’).  The Sponsor and Manager - Exos Capital Headquartered in New York City, Exos conducts diversified financial services and trading activities globally. Exos employs more than 80 professionals around the world including trading, banking, strategy, legal, compliance, and technology teams. Exos operates in a range of businesses and markets including in securities trading, commercial finance, asset management, alternative investments, technology ventures, and digital assets. Exos also operates world leading businesses and teams in AI (artificial intelligence), NLP (natural language processing) and other advanced data and computer sciences areas through its Claira team (link) and its newly acquired Pluribus Labs team (link). Exos operates both a registered broker-dealer and a registered investment advisor in the U.S. Detailed information on beneficial ownership, governance/control, and key personnel is available in Exos’ Form ADV SEC filing (Form ADV 2) that is filed for the registered investment advisor, Exos Asset Management. Similarly, for the recently acquired Pluribus Labs LLC, more detailed information on beneficial ownership, governance/control etc. available in their Form ADV SEC filing (Form ADV Pluribus ). Exos was formed in 2017 and is led by Brady Dougan, formally Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Credit Suisse. The following diagram is an organizational chart of Exos and its affiliates.  image1868×1049 52.2 KB  Operational and Local Partners Exos retains two partners relating to its mining operations for logistical, administration and on-site support: Navier, Inc. (link) and DeltaMining (link). Cabot is in the process of arranging for Navier, a mining operator, to provide operational oversight, security, and surveillance of the facility. While Navier is expected to provide these services for the foreseeable future, Exos reserves the right to replace Navier with a service provider who will provide equivalent services. In the event of a failure to return collateral under the Project terms, Navier will facilitate access to and liquidation of the Cabot miners. Alternatively, MakerDAO can designate an alternative agent to act as its service provider to facilitate the liquidation of collateral. While Cabot and Exos’ partners may change over the life of the project, Cabot will maintain at least one independent partner with a working knowledge of the Paraguay mining site who is capable of assisting a MakerDAO auction, sale, transport, or operational transition of Cabot’s miners in the unexpected event that Dai collateral is not returned under the terms of the transaction. Key Risk Factors and Risk Mitigation The principal risk of the Project is a failure by Cabot to return the collateral. The proposed transaction is arranged and structured to reduce the complexity of a collateral recovery while providing a range of recovery alternatives, as further discussed below. While not exhaustive, the following steps and alternatives to recovery are contemplated for the transaction:  image1127×519 53.3 KB  A second-order risk is a decrease in the value of the mining machines which proves more rapid than the preset valuation declines. While miners can have a useful life well in excess of 5 years, the project is assuming a full useful live of 5 years, a scheduled project termination at year 4, and a collateral half-life (return) of 2 years based on the annual returns of Dai. On the first anniversary, the scheduled return of Dai 3 million is based on a preset machine valuation decline of 20%: assumed aggregate machine valuation is revised from 15m to 12m, and the outstanding Dai is revised from 12m to 9m. If prevailing collateral valuations reflect an additional 20% decline (i.e. 40% in year 1, where [0.60 x 15m] now covers 9m) an impermanent loss may occur. Similarly on the second anniversary, the scheduled return of Dai 3 million is based on a preset machine valuation decline of $3m or 25% (i.e. $3m/12m or 25%). If prevailing collateral valuations reflect an additional 25% (50% in year 2, where [0.5 x 12m] now covers 6m) an impermanent loss may occur. In order to facilitate total transparency to Cabot’s operations, Exos and Cabot will provide real-time monitoring including (1) public wallet addresses to observe the holdings and transactions of wallets held at Cabot (2) real-time 24/7 webcams on the physical machines (3) and real-time dashboard indicating which machines are on site. For completeness, we repeat the risks considerations outlined in Q36 of our MIP6 proposal below: The primary risk of the proposal is that collateral is not returned and the risk mitigation measures are insufficient to result in a full return of the collateral and payment of the expected yield. Competition: Cabot’s obligations to MakerDAO are not reliant on the success of either Cabot or Exos generating any particular level of market share, business activity, or asset-based returns. That said, it is possible that overall lower levels of activity in Bitcoin mining and price levels (including in respect of other cryptocurrencies) could adversely impact the value of the mining machines and the associated mining revenue the project generates. General Industry Risks: An early and rapid decline in the value of mining machines and simultaneous failure of Cabot to return collateral could leave MakerDAO less well collateralized. To mitigate these risks, Exos has made its equity fully subordinated to the MakerDAO collateral return, and the preset annual returns of collateral progressively de-risk MakerDAO’s exposure. Legal and Regulatory Risks: Bitcoin has enjoyed a unique regulatory position relative to other coins and tokens; we do not expect its regulatory characterization to change. However, there is always the risk that regulators may assert broader jurisdiction over Bitcoin and, in particular, transactions effected on MakerDAO, including the issuance of DAI. We also do not expect there to by any regulatory changes that would materially impact the operation of the machines. That said, it is possible that regulatory changes could materially impact the profitability of the machines or ability to operate the machines, in which case they could be moved to one or more alternative countries with a more favorable regulatory regime in the event of unexpected legal or regulatory developments within the original host country. Interest Rate Risk: Unlike a conventional borrowing arrangement, annual preset returns of DAI collateral reduce the interest rate risk. For example, on the second anniversary, only one-half of the DAI collateral remains outstanding and subject to rises in interest rates. Notwithstanding the foregoing, borrowing at a fixed rate opposed to a variable rate can expose the lender to additional interest rate risk if interest rates increase. Commercial and Market Risks: It is possible that market conditions for Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies could negatively impact the profitability of this project. Further, if the market for mining machines drops dramatically early in the Project Term, the support provided by the subordinated equity will be diminished due to adverse changes to machine prices. Execution & Operating Related Risks: Our results of operations, including the levels of the project’s net revenues, expenses, net loss and other key metrics, may vary significantly in the future due to a variety of factors, some of which are outside of our control, and period-to-period comparisons of our operating results may not be meaningful. Accordingly, the results for any one quarter are not necessarily an indication of future performance. Factors that may cause fluctuations in our annual financial results include:   (i) the amount and timing of operating expenses related to our new business operations and infrastructure;   (ii) fluctuations in the price of bitcoin; and   (iii) general economic, industry and market conditions.   Illiquidity Risks: The Collateral or the tokens evidencing rights to the Collateral may be or become illiquid which may affect MakerDAO’s ability to exit such asset. Cyber-Related Risks: Cabot and its Operator, Exos Capital, and their third-party service providers are subject to risks associated with “cybersecurity” breaches. “Cybersecurity” is a generic term used to describe the technology, processes and practices designed to protect networks, systems, computers, programs and data from unauthorized access or manipulation by other computer users and the efforts to avoid the resulting damage and disruption of hardware and software systems, loss or corruption of data and/or misappropriation of confidential information. Cybersecurity breaches may be the result of intentional actions (such as an attempt by a third party to fraudulently induce employees, customers, third-party service providers or other users of systems to disclose sensitive information in order to gain access to Cabot, Exos data) or unintentional events. Any such breach could expose the arrangement to financial loss (including those associated with the forensic analysis of the origin and scope of the breach and costs of increased and upgraded information technology systems and/or cybersecurity countermeasures), the disruption of business, unauthorized use of proprietary information, litigation, the dissemination of confidential and proprietary information or reputational damage. Disruptions in the market for DAI and the Ethereum blockchain: can alter the timing of collateral returns. In the event that transactions to either acquire or transmit DAI are subject to disruption (a “Market Disruption”), Exos will notify MakerDAO of such disruption via the MakerDAO forum or alternative means. A Market Disruption means any of:   (i) transactions submitted to the Ethereum blockchain are materially delayed or failing,   (ii) the MakerDAO protocol is reported to be down or inoperative,   (iii) gas prices for a transaction on the Ethereum network exceed the equivalent of $200, as reported by Etherscan.io or a similar data source,   (iv) Exos is unable to acquire DAI for 1.00 US dollar (taking into consideration all historically consistent transaction costs).   Cabot reserves the right to delay the return of collateral and other payment obligations during a Market Disruption until such time such Market Disruption is remedied or no longer occurring. In the event that the Market Disruption (iv) is continuing for more than 90 calendar days, Cabot will convert Dai quantities to U.S. Dollars and remit a market equivalent amount of said U.S. Dollars in Ether. COUNTRY RISK As described herein, Cabot’s operations and machines are expected to be located in Paraguay during the Project Term. While there is no certainty relating to national laws or regulation, Cabot’s assets relate to the mining machines and not the physical site, and in the event of unexpected changes, Cabot’s machines may be relocated outside Paraguay. Nonetheless, recent industry articles have reported a generally constructive national view of cryptocurrencies and mining activities. Neither Cabot nor Exos are representing any view relating to the regulatory environment in Paraguay or any other country. See “Paraguayan Bill Regulating Crypto Mining and Trading Moves Closer to Law”, Coindesk, Andres Engler, May 25, 2022 (link). From the article:  “Paraguay’s Chamber of Deputies on Wednesday approved by a 40-12 vote a bill regulating crypto mining and trading. The country’s Senate in December had already passed similar legislation, and the bill will now return to that body with the Chamber of Deputies’ modifications. Once the Senate approves the changes, the pending law would move to the executive branch, which hasn’t yet signaled whether it will sign or veto. Speaking with CoinDesk last year, Carlos Rejala – one of the bill’s authors – said the legislation aims to attract international miners to Paraguay, which has one of the lowest electricity rates in Latin America at around 5 cents per kilowatt-hour. In the debate, Congressman Tadeo Rojas (ANR-Central) argued against the legislation, noting that the Chamber of Deputies’ budget committee recommended rejection. He added the impact on job creation is low compared with the energy consumption required by mining companies. The incubating Legal & Transactional Services core unit (“LTS”) has reviewed the Cabot Renewable Energy Crypto Mining (MIP6 Follow On). Recommendation: LTS recommends that the Maker DAO community not greenlight this application. Rationale The MIP67/MIP6 application remains incomplete and leaves out important commercial and legal details. Exos Capital has not proposed a mechanism for Maker to integrate in the real world in respect of the loan or the proposed security interest over the mining machines. Exos Capital appears to leave this decision with the Maker community. Exos indicates that Cabot will own the mining machines. What is unclear from the proposal is whether Cabot (the Delaware entity) or another entity (a Cabot affiliate in Paraguay) will actually have ownership of the mining assets in Paraguay. It is not uncommon for a US entity to form a subsidiary in the local jurisdiction to own and operate the locally-based assets. Maker would not have direct access to the mining equipment itself as collateral security. This weakens the security package. Although I recognize that the membership interests in Cabot will likely be easier to foreclose. An “all assets” security in regards to Cabot would be appropriate. The security interest would include the “Unwind Expenses Wallet” and the agreements under which Cabot acquires the mining machines. Without a doubt, any action to remove the machines from Paraguay will require some level of activity in Paraguay. Exos has not provided any direct visibility on the agreements for the operational, settlement, etc. of the mining machines. As a secured party, Maker will want to ensure that, in the event that it exercises its collateral rights, it will have the necessary contracts to ensure the on-going operation and/or removal of the machines. Exos has not provided an over-arching funds flow diagram that describes each step of the funding and repayment process. The mechanism to activate the assets in the Unwind Expenses Wallet is not clear. If Cabot has an obligation to pay Maker from this wallet and does not, what happens? What is Maker’s recourse? The proposal requires due diligence of Exos’ larger “hydro-powered operation” in Paraguay. For instance, if there is a temporary shortage of hydroelectric power (irrespective of the reason), how will Exos prioritize its mining machines? Are all of Exos’ machines curtailed on a pro rata basis? What happens if there is an insurable event in respect of the financed mining machines – does Cabot repay the loan immediately? How has Cabot arranged for its insurance coverage? Other than briefly, Exos has not addressed any potential political risk issues in Paraguay, particularly in respect of expropriation, permitting and the like. While an interesting proposition to marry DAI with Bitcoin mining, the proposed transaction has many of the features of a single-asset, project financing. The proposed transaction will require, in my view as an experienced project finance lawyer, substantial time for LTS and @Real-World-Finance to identify and mitigate the project associated risks and bring a transaction to fruition.

Maker Community Subject Matter Expertise & Embedded Optionality in Unexpected Recovery Scenario Based on the community’s subject matter expertise and expected expansion of MakerDAO’s real world activities, Exos believes that it’s suboptimal to prewire a single recovery mechanism which would automatically trigger an auctioning, other selling, or miner operation without consideration of prevailing market conditions or potential real world finance synergies. Exos believes that providing agents and service providers throughout the term (rather than hard-wired liquidations) is likely to preserve beneficial options and reduce the possibilities for conflicts of interest.     CabotRenewableTeam:     The embedded optionality prescribed in this proposal provides MakerDAO with assurances, that in the unlikely event of default, the Maker Community can take comfort in the fact that Cabot assets can integrate with whatever strategy MakerDAO elects to pursuit within the crypto mining asset class. It is with care that we propose four clearly defined liquidation routes, opposed to one that is hard-wired and lacking in strategic considerations.    MIP6: Cabot Renewable Energy Crypto Mining   So as I think about moving into this asset class. The logic is not: because the value of our collateral (ASICs, land, PPE, PPAs) will fall with BTC, an asset Maker is already exposed to, we should avoid it. But rather, is this an asset that Maker can have an EDGE in understanding and lending against. Most of our RWAs thus far have been imported from competitive TradFi markets. We should be thinking: what sorts of assets are UNIQUELY fitted to Maker lending rails?   To the point @teej raised in our original MIP6 (and quoted here), while we do not presently know Maker’s “EDGE,” we do know that MakerDAO will have an EDGE when/if it chooses to deepen its ties to the crypto mining asset class. The remedy herein preserves that flexibility as MakerDAO’s strategy within the asset class continues to evolve. I agree with @teej from a strategic perspective. And the Maker community’s adoption of a strategic preference may include the assumption of certain legal and contractual risks. The Maker community needs to simply understand whether it is (or is not) assuming certain legal and contractual risks.     CabotRenewableTeam:  closing documentation would encompass a “complete security” package   What is a “complete security” package? As a project finance lawyer, my view of “complete” is a security interest in the equity of the borrower (Cabot), the underlying assets (the mining machines), Cabot’s contractual rights, and any other asset of Cabot. Even though Cabot may own the machines, as a secured party, I will want to ensure that no other person could have a priority security interest in the machines themselves. A security interest in Cabot’s equity does not guarantee this protection. I appreciate the basic funds flow. But there are outstanding questions - who is the proposed exchange agent? Does Cabot or Exos have the contractual relationship with the exchange agent? If Exos, how do you propose that Maker steps into Cabot’s shoes to access USD/DAI conversion in the event Maker exercises its security interest in the Cabot shares? Greenlight Recommendation RWF is comfortable issuing the following for the benefit of MKR token holders who may participate in the upcoming green-light poll: Summary: Though hash power-backed lending is of long-term strategic value to Maker (and I commend Cabot for recognizing and capitalizing on the intersection of Green x Hash-Power Backed Lending), the sector is significantly riskier than any of our existing lending activity, whether crypto-loans or RWAs. As such, Maker’s foray into hash-power backed lending should benefit from fundamentals stronger than those inherent to this proposal. Maker has recently been approached by a number of players that are proposing significantly more suitable structures and terms for a similar product. Some of these alternative structures may enable Maker to build out a more scaleable engine for Hash-Power Backed Loan Obligations (HBLOs), a more composable and trust-minimized form of RWAs. We should be wary of jumping on the first HBL opportunity that arrives on our door-step, not because Cabot has done anything wrong but because there will be many more where it came from. Let’s remember that the power dynamics have shifted: Maker has earned the right to be picky. As I will continue to say ad nauseum, for RWAs to be profitable and provide value to token holders (today), MakerDAO should be focusing on wholesale-esc relationships that scale. I.e. build a commercial/legal/technical structure once, underwrite the underwriter, and drip additional funding to them as the vault seasons and the underwriter performs. MakerDAO ought not to be a jack of all trades and master of none. It wants to empower specialist lenders to execute in their niches, not to build out a bloated and ineffective credit underwriting department. I believe that this proposal presents poor risk-adjusted return to the protocol, in both an absolute and relative sense. I recommend MKR token holders not greenlight this collateral. Risks   Ad-Hoc vs. Wholesale: For Maker to expand into hash-power backed lending, an esoteric space, it should do so via a wholesale, repeatable model. Instead of lending against a small, potentially one-off project (Cabot - Paraguay), we’d like to underwrite an underwriter who is financially aligned and knows BTC hash-power backed lending well. A la the HVB deal, this allows Maker to take advantage of a more turn-key, aligned yield solution.   Size is a Feature: In all business sectors, especially during turbulence, the strong get stronger. BTC miners are in tatters right now, offering firesale asset opportunities for the well-capitalized—Maker should ally only with the strongest.    Low BTC price tends to cause consolidation as the strong ingest (at a huge discount) and integrate the assets of the weak. Relative to other miners in space, Cabot is a relatively modest operation. Maker should, at least as a pilot, be backing miners who will (in the long-run) benefit from, rather than suffer in downturns. This means backing large existing BTC mining operators and operators flush with cash. Given Cabot’s break-even BTC price of $16K and meter rate of 4.5 cents, Cabot is in a relatively strong position. The fundamental economics, to some extent, offset the smaller footprint.    Leverage Profile: Bitcoin mining risks are a derivative of BTC spot risks. As such, lending against machines with a certain productive potential (hashrate) to create BTC can generate a loss if the leverage is too high. The going-in 80% Maker attachment point (All-in LTV closer to 75% with Unwind Cash Trap) on the underlying asset is higher than the market standard and about equivalent to the leverage profile of a mortgage, a patently safer asset. The risk of principal loss is thus high as structured.   Though the loan is fully-amortizing, the year one principal risk is moderate.    Focus/Expertise: Exos does a lot of different things, including securities trading, commercial finance, asset management, alternative investment, technology ventures, digital investments, AI, and NLP. Though Exos manages a Morgan Creek BTC fund, this strikes me as a sophisticated, but generalist crypto financial services shop. For our pilot in BTC hash power backed lending, Maker should focus on long-standing specialists in the space.   Though Exos has been mining since 2019, the firm’s focus has been on Zen and Zcash. Surely know-how is transferable, but not perfectly.    Jurisdictional Risk: It is unclear how strong Maker’s rights and remedies as a senior lender would be in Paraguay. Again, Maker’s foray into hash-power backed lending should entail relatively secure fundamentals to make up for the inherent risk of the asset class.   Term: Most hash-power backed loans have 2-3 year terms. Taking on a five-year term, especially fixed at 6% interest rate exposes Maker to repayment, duration, and interest rate risk. The fully-amortizing nature of the loan offsets the longer term to some extent.   Opportunities   BTC Mining: Crypto economies, digital states, are secured in no small part due to Bitcoin. As the Decentral bank of crypto, Maker’s financing of mining is akin to national security spending. Cabot’s MIP-6 provides Maker an opportunity to pilot a lending business within a sector that we could uniquely generate an edge in (unlike a lot of structured credit).   Profit + Sustainability: Not only are Cabot’s miners powered via green energy (in this case geothermal), but Maker’s financing of green energy in this case does not sacrifice profit. Paraguay’s geothermal supply is commercially competitive if not cheaper than fossil fuel sources. This can be evidence in Cabot’s 4.5 cent meter rate.   Management Reputation: Exos, Cabot’s parent company, is headed by the former CEO of Credit Suisse, Brady Dougan.   Jurisdictional Diversification: As of yet, Maker has no RWA footprint in South America. Given the conciliatory stance taken by many South and Central American administrations, this jurisdictional diversification could strengthen Maker’s regulatory position.   Fully Amortizing: as opposed to a bullet term, the Cabot financing structure contemplates progressive/straight-line repayment of principal over the course of the loan.

To cover expenses associated with a liquidation of Cabot and the miners, Cabot will cause Exos Capital to deposit the first $250,000 of mining revenues generated by the Cabot miners in a wallet held at Cabot (the “Unwind Expenses Wallet”). The Unwind Expenses Wallet will hold cryptocurrency generated by the miners, and will true-up on a quarterly basis to maintain approximately $250,000 USD equivalent in available funds. By “true up” we mean that if there is an amount below $250,000 USD in the Unwind Expenses Wallet at the end of the relevant quarter, Exos Capital will be required to deposit the amount of such deficiency in the Unwind Expenses Wallet. Likewise, if there happens to be an amount of funds in the Unwind Expenses Wallet in excess of $250,000 USD at the end of any quarter, the amount of such surplus will be returned to Exos Capital. The funds held in the Unwind Expenses Wallet are available to pay for the costs of liquidation of the collateral as detailed below.
